title: 1116-C2
statement: C2. "Is the bit string periodic?" oracletime limit per test4 secondsmemory limit per test1024 megabytesinputstandard inputoutputstandard outputImplement a quantum oracle on $$$N$$$ qubits which checks whether the bits in the input vector $$$\\vec{x}$$$ form a periodic bit string (i.e., implements the function $$$f(\\vec{x}) = 1$$$ if $$$\\vec{x}$$$ is periodic, and 0 otherwise).A bit string of length $$$N$$$ is considered periodic with period $$$P$$$ ($$$1 \\le P \\le N - 1$$$) if for all $$$i \\in [0, N - P - 1]$$$ $$$x_i = x_{i + P}$$$. Note that $$$P$$$ does not have to divide $$$N$$$ evenly; for example, bit string"01010"is periodic with period $$$P = 2$$$.You have to implement an operation which takes the following inputs:an array of $$$N$$$ ($$$2 \\le N \\le 7$$$) qubits $$$x$$$ in an arbitrary state (input register),a qubit $$$y$$$ in an arbitrary state (output qubit),and performs a transformation $$$|x\\rangle|y\\rangle \\rightarrow |x\\rangle|y \\oplus f(x)\\rangle$$$. The operation doesn't have an output; its "output" is the state in which it leaves the qubits. Note that the input register $$$x$$$ has to remain unchanged after applying the operation.Your code should have the following signature:namespace Solution {open Microsoft.Quantum.Primitive;open Microsoft.Quantum.Canon;operation Solve (x : Qubit[], y : Qubit) : Unit {body (...) {// your code here}adjoint auto;}}Note: the operation has to have an adjoint specified for it;adjoint automeans that the adjoint will be generated automatically. For details on adjoint, seeOperation Definitions.You are not allowed to use measurements in your operation.
